title: How to Make Cinnamon Crisps

steps.headline: Preheat your oven and get out baking sheets.
steps.description: Turn on the oven to 350 degrees F (180 C). Get out one large or two small baking sheets and set them next to your work station.

steps.headline: Combine the sugar and cinnamon.
steps.description: Get out a small prep bowl and measure one cup (200 g) sugar and one tablespoon ground cinnamon into it. Stir the mixture until the cinnamon is evenly distributed. For slightly spicy crisps, consider adding a few pinches of cayenne pepper.

steps.headline: Melt the butter and brush the tortillas.
steps.description: Melt 1/2 cup (113 g) of butter in a small bowl. Get out three small flour tortillas and set them on the baking sheet. Dip a pastry brush into the butter and spread it across the tortillas, so they're completely coated. If your butter starts firming up, return it to the microwave and heat it for a few seconds.

steps.headline: Coat the tortillas with cinnamon sugar and repeat this on the other side.
steps.description: Use your fingertips or a spoon to sprinkle the cinnamon sugar mixture over the tortillas with the melted butter. They should be coated with the mixture. Turn them over and brush them with butter before coating these sides with the mixture. You won't need to grease the baking sheets because the tortillas have so much butter on them. They shouldn't stick to the sheets.

steps.headline: Bake the tortilla cinnamon crisps.
steps.description: Put the baking sheet in the preheated oven and bake the crisps for 15 to 17 minutes. They should become very dark and crunchy. Carefully take the baking sheet out of the oven and let the crisps cool completely. Use your hands to break them into smaller pieces. Consider serving the cinnamon crisps with coffee or vanilla ice cream.

steps.headline: Whisk the dry ingredients.
steps.description: Measure three cups (360 g) unbleached all-purpose flour into a large mixing bowl and add one teaspoon of kosher salt and one tablespoon of ground cinnamon. Whisk the dry ingredients to incorporate the cinnamon. Set the dry mixture aside while you make the wet dough mixture.

steps.headline: Cream the butter and sugars.
steps.description: Soften one cup (226 g) unsalted butter and put it into a large mixing bowl. Add 1/2 cup (100 g) brown sugar and 3/4 cup (175 g) granulated sugar. Beat the butter and sugars using a hand or stand mixer with a paddle attachment. Cream the mixture on medium speed for about one minute. The mixture should become lighter in color and a little fluffy.

steps.headline: Beat in the egg, vanilla, and lemon zest.
steps.description: Add one egg to the bowl with the creamed butter and sugar along with one teaspoon of pure vanilla extract. Zest one lemon and add it to the mixture. Beat the egg, vanilla, and lemon zest into the mixture on low speed. You'll probably need to stop and scrape down the sides of the bowl to ensure that the zest and vanilla are completely mixed in.

steps.headline: Stir in the flour mixture and refrigerate the dough.
steps.description: Slowly stir in the dry mixture on low speed, so it doesn't fly out of the mixing bowl. Keep stirring until the dry mixture is incorporated and the dough forms. It should start pulling away from the sides of the bowl. Pat the dough into a disk shape and wrap it in plastic wrap. Refrigerate the dough for one hour. Chilling the dough will make the cookies tender and flaky.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven and prepare the baking sheets.
steps.description: Once the dough has chilled, turn the oven on to 350 degrees F (180 C). Get out a few rimmed baking sheets and spray them with cooking spray. Tear a few sheets of parchment paper and lay them on the baking sheets. Set these aside while you roll out the dough. You can remove the dough from the refrigerator at this point, so it softens a little. This will make it easier to roll out.

steps.headline: Make the egg wash. Get out a small prep bowl and crack one egg into it.
steps.description: Pour in 2 tablespoons of milk and use a fork to whisk the egg wash. Set the egg wash aside while you make the sweet topping. The egg wash will help the cinnamon sugar topping stick to the cookies and will give them a rich golden color.

steps.headline: Combine the cinnamon and sugar for the topping.
steps.description: To make the sweet topping, get out a small prep bowl and measure out 1/4 cup (50 g) granulated sugar into it. Add 1 tablespoon of ground cinnamon and use a spoon to stir the topping. Set the sweet topping aside while you roll out the cookies. The cinnamon should be completely stirred into the sugar.

steps.headline: Roll and cut the dough into rectangles.
steps.description: Unwrap the dough and divide it into three pieces. Sprinkle a little flour on your work surface and place one of the pieces on it. Use a rolling pin to roll the piece into a rectangle that's 1/8th-inch (3 mm) thick. Take a knife or fluted pastry wheel and cut the dough into long rectangles that are 1 1/2 to 2-inches (3 to 5 cm) long. Repeat this with the two other pieces of dough. You can also use cookie cutters to just cut out shapes. Or you can cut the dough into squares instead of rectangles.

steps.headline: Brush the cookies with the egg wash and sprinkle them with the topping.
steps.description: Set all of the pastry rectangles on the prepared baking sheets. Leave 1/2-inch (12 mm) of space between the rectangles. Dip a pastry brush in the egg wash and brush the wash over each rectangle. Sprinkle them with the cinnamon sugar mixture. Sprinkle a lot of the sweet mixture over the pastry squares, since this will also help them crisp up.

steps.headline: Bake the Swiss cinnamon crisp cookies.
steps.description: Put the baking sheets in the oven and cook the cookies for 10 to 12 minutes. They should turn dark brown. Remove the baking sheets from the oven and let the cookies cool for a few minutes on the sheet before you remove them to a wire rack. Let the cookies completely cool before serving or storing them. To help the cookies bake evenly, you may want to rotate the baking sheets halfway through the cooking time. You can store the cookies for up to 2 weeks, if they're in an airtight container.
